The aim is to improve the involvement of GPs in the NDIS.

clusters.title: Maha is backing this ‘natural’ infertility treatment. Is it the right’s path to limiting IVF?
clusters.neutral_headline: Maha is backing this ‘natural’ infertility treatment. Is it the right’s path to limiting IVF?: Conservatives are promoting ‘restorative reproductive medicine’ instead of Trump’s promise to support IVF. Doctors are worriedFor Erica L and her husband, in-vitro fertilization was the “nuclear option”.After two years of trying to conceive, Erica and her husband had no idea why they could not have a baby. Doctors said only that they had “unexplained infertility”, a non-diagnosis of a diagnosis that is given to an estimated 15% of people trying to conceive. Erica was not ideologically opposed to trying IVF, but felt daunted by the price and unpredictability. Continue reading

ai_summary: Conservatives are promoting "restorative reproductive medicine".
This is instead of Trump's promise to support IVF.
Doctors are expressing concerns about the shift.
Erica L. and her husband faced unexplained infertility.
IVF was considered a daunting option due to cost.

clusters.title: Alarming levels of Pfas in blood of those living near US air force base, study finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Alarming levels of Pfas in blood of those living near US air force base, study finds: Toxic ‘forever chemicals’ were found at a level 10 times higher than people who did not work in contaminated zoneNew research shows alarming levels of Pfas in the blood of people living or working near a US air force base responsible for polluting drinking water with high levels of the dangerous “forever chemicals”, a new state regulatory report has found.The levels are high enough in those who lived and worked near the Cannon air force base in Curry county to raise health concerns – about 10 times above the levels of those in the region who did not work in the contaminated zone. The pollution stems from a type of Pfas-laden firefighting foam the military has used across the nation, and the types of compounds found at high levels in participants’ blood were also commonly used in foam. Continue reading

items.title: Alarming levels of Pfas in blood of those living near US air force base, study finds

The pollution stems from a type of Pfas-laden firefighting foam the military has used across the nation, and the types of compounds found at high levels in participants’ blood were also commonly used in foam. Continue reading...
items.content: Toxic ‘forever chemicals’ were found at a level 10 times higher than people who did not work in contaminated zoneNew research shows alarming levels of Pfas in the blood of people living or working near a US air force base responsible for polluting drinking water with high levels of the dangerous “forever chemicals”, a new state regulatory report has found.The levels are high enough in those who lived and worked near the Cannon air force base in Curry county to raise health concerns – about 10 times above the levels of those in the region who did not work in the contaminated zone. The pollution stems from a type of Pfas-laden firefighting foam the military has used across the nation, and the types of compounds found at high levels in participants’ blood were also commonly used in foam. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A study found alarming levels of PFAS near a US air force base.
Levels were ten times higher than in those not in the zone.
The contamination is linked to firefighting foam.
The foam contains dangerous "forever chemicals".
The findings raise health concerns for residents.

clusters.title: Eau de courgette: rise in foodie perfumes may be linked to weight-loss drugs
clusters.neutral_headline: Eau de courgette: rise in foodie perfumes may be linked to weight-loss drugs: ‘Gourmand’ fragrances with notes of biscuit or cherries are also trending among young consumers onlineA rise in the number of sweet, food-scented perfumes on the market could be linked to an increase in the use of weight-loss medication, according to the market research firm Mintel.Food-inspired fragrances, with scent profiles that feature vanilla, coffee and caramel and referred to in the industry as “gourmand” perfumes, have surged in popularity in the past three years. Launches of sugary-scented, dessert-themed fragrances increased by 24% last year alone, Mintel said. Continue reading

items.title: Eau de courgette: rise in foodie perfumes may be linked to weight-loss drugs

Launches of sugary-scented, dessert-themed fragrances increased by 24% last year alone, Mintel said. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Food-scented perfumes are increasing in popularity.
The trend may be linked to weight-loss medication use.
"Gourmand" perfumes are trending among young consumers.
Launches of dessert-themed fragrances increased by 24%.
Mintel is the market research firm reporting this trend.

items.content: Could her comments instil a new sense of confidence in those using the drugs and quieten the critics?

Her openness could encourage others to discuss their experiences with similar treatments.
The conversation might reduce the stigma associated with anti-obesity drugs.
Critics of these medications may face a challenge as more people share their stories.
Williams's comments could boost confidence in those using weight-loss drugs.

clusters.title: Air pollution from oil and gas causes 90,000 premature US deaths each year, says new study
clusters.neutral_headline: Air pollution from oil and gas causes 90,000 premature US deaths each year, says new study

items.title: Air pollution from oil and gas causes 90,000 premature US deaths each year, says new study
items.standfirst: Study analyzed health impacts of fossil fuels from exploration to end use, and found communities of color bear brunt of harmAir pollution from oil and gas causes more than 90,000 premature deaths and sickens hundreds of thousands of people across the US each year, a new study shows, with disproportionately high impacts on communities of color.More than 10,000 annual pre-term births are attributable to fine particulate matter from oil and gas, the authors found, also linking 216,000 annual childhood-onset asthma cases to the sector’s nitrogen dioxide emissions and 1,610 annual lifetime cancer cases to its hazardous air pollutants. Continue reading...
items.content: Study analyzed health impacts of fossil fuels from exploration to end use, and found communities of color bear brunt of harmAir pollution from oil and gas causes more than 90,000 premature deaths and sickens hundreds of thousands of people across the US each year, a new study shows, with disproportionately high impacts on communities of color.More than 10,000 annual pre-term births are attributable to fine particulate matter from oil and gas, the authors found, also linking 216,000 annual childhood-onset asthma cases to the sector’s nitrogen dioxide emissions and 1,610 annual lifetime cancer cases to its hazardous air pollutants. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A new study links oil and gas air pollution to 90,000 premature deaths annually in the US.
The study found communities of color experience disproportionately high health impacts.
Over 10,000 preterm births yearly are linked to fine particulate matter from oil and gas.
216,000 annual childhood asthma cases are connected to nitrogen dioxide emissions.
Hazardous air pollutants from the sector cause 1,610 annual lifetime cancer cases.

clusters.title: Wes Streeting’s row with pharma firms grows as they reject NHS drug pricing offer
clusters.neutral_headline: Wes Streeting’s row with pharma firms grows as they reject NHS drug pricing offer

items.title: Wes Streeting’s row with pharma firms grows as they reject NHS drug pricing offer
items.standfirst: Drugmakers fail to meet health secretary’s latest offer, meaning ‘unsustainable’ rebate scheme will stay in placeA row between Wes Streeting and pharmaceutical companies has intensified after drugmakers rejected the health secretary’s latest offer on NHS drug pricing.The two sides failed to reach agreement by a midday deadline on Friday, meaning the mechanism under which the health service claws back some of the money it pays for medicines will continue at a rate the industry said was “unsustainable” and could ultimately disadvantage patients. Continue reading...
items.content: Drugmakers fail to meet health secretary’s latest offer, meaning ‘unsustainable’ rebate scheme will stay in placeA row between Wes Streeting and pharmaceutical companies has intensified after drugmakers rejected the health secretary’s latest offer on NHS drug pricing.The two sides failed to reach agreement by a midday deadline on Friday, meaning the mechanism under which the health service claws back some of the money it pays for medicines will continue at a rate the industry said was “unsustainable” and could ultimately disadvantage patients. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Drugmakers rejected the health secretary's latest offer regarding NHS drug pricing.
The deadline for an agreement between the two sides was midday on Friday.
The current rebate scheme will continue at a rate deemed unsustainable by the industry.
The industry suggests the scheme could disadvantage patients in the long run.
The row between Wes Streeting and pharmaceutical companies has intensified.

items.standfirst: The medium-sized herbivore once roamed the floodplains of what is now the Island's south-west coast.
items.content: The medium-sized herbivore once roamed the floodplains of what is now the Island's south-west coast.

ai_summary: A new dinosaur species has been named after a record-breaking sailor.
The herbivore was medium-sized and lived on floodplains.
The dinosaur once roamed the southwest coast of what is now an island.
The naming honors the sailor's achievements in a unique way.
The discovery adds to the understanding of prehistoric life.

clusters.title: As measles gains ground in US, Texas offers lessons from its outbreak
clusters.neutral_headline: As measles gains ground in US, Texas offers lessons from its outbreak

items.title: As measles gains ground in US, Texas offers lessons from its outbreak
items.standfirst: Vaccine-hesitant communities might benefit from free treatment centers and smaller vaccination clinicsThe measles outbreak in Texas has officially ended, but as cases continue to be detected in other parts of the US state health experts are warning of the need to prepare for outbreaks in undervaccinated communities, especially as anti-vaccine beliefs are becoming more prominent during the Trump administration.So far this year, 1,356 confirmed measles cases, largely from 32 outbreaks, have been reported across the US – compared with last year’s entire total of 285 cases and 16 outbreaks. While the Texas outbreak initially drove the case counts, other US outbreaks are now contributing in increasing numbers. Continue reading...
items.content: Vaccine-hesitant communities might benefit from free treatment centers and smaller vaccination clinicsThe measles outbreak in Texas has officially ended, but as cases continue to be detected in other parts of the US state health experts are warning of the need to prepare for outbreaks in undervaccinated communities, especially as anti-vaccine beliefs are becoming more prominent during the Trump administration.So far this year, 1,356 confirmed measles cases, largely from 32 outbreaks, have been reported across the US – compared with last year’s entire total of 285 cases and 16 outbreaks. While the Texas outbreak initially drove the case counts, other US outbreaks are now contributing in increasing numbers. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The measles outbreak in Texas has officially ended, but cases continue elsewhere.
1,356 confirmed measles cases have been reported across the US this year.
These cases stem from 32 outbreaks, significantly higher than last year's total.
Health experts warn of preparing for outbreaks in undervaccinated communities.
Anti-vaccine beliefs are becoming more prominent, especially during the Trump administration.

items.content: Manufacturers who do not make products healthier within 18 months may face action, the government says.

ai_summary: Baby food manufacturers must make products healthier within 18 months.
The government has issued this directive to baby food companies.
Companies failing to comply may face potential government action.
The goal is to improve the nutritional quality of baby food products.
This initiative aims to protect the health of infants and young children.
